messages.subject: Re: Question: How do you handle unschooling w/ the school district?
messages.msgSnippet: ***How do you handle unschooling w/ the school district? *** Try here: http://nhen.org/ Or, tell us where you are.  Each state is different and some districts
messages.messageBody:
***How do you handle unschooling w/ the school district? ***


Try here: http://nhen.org/

Or, tell us where you are. Each state is different and some districts
differ with the state.

Deb Lewis

messages.subject: Re: [unschoolingbasics] Question: How do you handle unschooling w/ the school district?
messages.msgSnippet: ... A lot depends on were you live. In South Carolina I have to join an association, sign a statement that we are doing equivilant to the state. That s all the
messages.messageBody:
On 4/3/06, hecares4uall <hecares4uall@...> wrote:
>
> A newbie!
> Colleen
>

A lot depends on were you live. In South Carolina I have to join an
association, sign a statement that we are doing equivilant to the state.
That's all the legally need. Now what they want may be a different thing.
Read your state law and give them only what is required.

Lydia

--
Be the person you want your children to become.

messages.subject: Re: [unschoolingbasics] Question: How do you handle unschooling w/ the school district?
messages.msgSnippet: ... It depends on what your state requirements are.  Some states you simply notify the school district of your intent to homeschool and you never need do
messages.messageBody:
On 4/3/06, hecares4uall <hecares4uall@...> wrote:
>
> A newbie!
> Colleen


It depends on what your state requirements are. Some states you simply
notify the school district of your intent to homeschool and you never need
do anything ever again. While other states have more stringent
requirements. It is important to know what your state requirements are. I
have found it very interesting that when some parents have notified their
districts of intent to homeschool the local district will make homeschooling
sound like it is difficult with tons of hoops to jump through and lots of
requirements. Yet, none of these hoops are required by the state. It's a
"scare tactic" to make parents think it would be just easier to keep their
child in the school system. Or they are made up by a school district
employee who doesn't know the state laws.

If you are living in a state that has lots of requirements, the best thing
to do is to look for an unschooling group in your state. I bet most of the
states have a "Your state Unschooling" yahoogroup. These families are
masters at how to word unschooling lifestyles into schoolish looking
jargon. :)





--
Michelle
Independent Kitchen Consultant #413652
The Pampered Chef
